Author full names: Manabe, Toshie (36613440200); Thuy, Pham Thi Phuong (57208095585); van Can, Vu (48161787400); Takasaki, Jin (7004507380); Huyen, Dinh Thi Thanh (55259838300); Chau, Nguyen Thi My (50361032300); Shimbo, Takuro (7005992346); Ha, Bui Thi Thu (56209932000); Izumi, Shinyu (7201411484); Hanh, Tran Thuy (24171135700)
Title: Impact of educational intervention concerning awareness and behaviors relating to avian influenza (H5N1) in a high-risk population in Vietnam
Affiliations: National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; NCGM-BMH Medical Collaboration Center, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Health Department of Ninh Binh Province, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Manabe, Toshie, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Thuy, Pham Thi Phuong, NCGM-BMH Medical Collaboration Center, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Can, Vu, Health Department of Ninh Binh Province, Viet Nam; Takasaki, Jin, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Huyen, Dinh Thi Thanh, NCGM-BMH Medical Collaboration Center, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chau, Nguyen Thi My, Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shimbo, Takuro, Research Institute, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Ha, Bui Thi Thu, Health Department of Ninh Binh Province, Viet Nam; Izumi, Shinyu, Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Hanh, Tran Thuy, Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Background: Early initiation of treatment is essential for treatment of avian influenza A/H5N1 viral infection in humans, as the disease can lead to rapid development of severe pneumonia which can result in death. Contact with infected poultry is known to be a significant risk factor for contraction of H5N1 infection. However, handling and encountering poultry are a part of most peoples' daily lives, especially in rural communities in Vietnam where epidemic outbreaks among poultry have been continuously reported. Enhancing proper knowledge relating to H5N1 and to the importance of early initiation of treatment are crucial. The aim of this study was to develop an effective educational program to enhance awareness of H5N1 and motivate people to access to health care earlier when H5N1 infection is suspected or likely. Methodology and Principal Findings: A study was conducted in two agricultural communities (intervention and control groups) in the Ninh Binh province in Vietnam, where epidemic outbreaks of avian influenza have recently occurred in birds. A unique educational intervention was developed and provided to the intervention group, and no intervention was provided to the control group. A knowledge, attitude and practice (KAP) survey was conducted in both groups with a face-to-face interview by trained local healthcare workers at time points before and after the educational intervention. KAP scores were compared between the different time points and between the groups. How educational intervention influenced awareness relating to H5N1 and accessibility of healthcare in the population was analyzed. The study indicated an increased awareness of H5N1 and increased reliance on local health care workers. Conclusions: The novel educational program which was developed for this study impacted awareness of H5N1, and resulted in more people seeking early access to healthcare, and also resulted in earlier medical intervention for patients with H5N1 avian influenza infection in Vietnam. © 2011 Manabe et al. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Analysis of factors lowering sensitivity of interferon-γ release assay for tuberculosis
Affiliations: NCGM-BMH Medical Collaboration Center, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The Research Institute of Tuberculosis, Japan Anti-Tuberculosis Association, Kiyose, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hang, Nguyen Thi Le, NCGM-BMH Medical Collaboration Center, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Lien, Luu Thi, Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Nobuyuki, Department of Respiratory Medicine, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Shimbo, Takuro, Department of Clinical Research and Informatics, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Sakurada, Shinsaku, Department of Respiratory Diseases, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Thuong, Pham Huu, Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hong, Lethi, Department of Biochemistry, Hematology and Blood Transfusion, Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tam, Dobang, Department of Biochemistry, Hematology and Blood Transfusion, Hanoi Lung Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hijikata, Minako, Department of Respiratory Diseases, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Matsushita, Ikumi, Department of Respiratory Diseases, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Background: Imperfect sensitivity of interferon-γ release assay (IGRA) is a potential problem to detect tuberculosis. We made a thorough investigation of the factors that can lead to false negativity of IGRA. Methods: We recruited 543 patients with new smear-positive pulmonary tuberculosis in Hanoi, Viet Nam. At diagnosis, peripheral blood was collected and IGRA (QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube) was performed. Clinical and epidemiological information of the host and pathogen was collected. The test sensitivity was calculated and factors negatively influencing IGRA results were evaluated using a logistic regression model in 504 patients with culture-confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis. Results: The overall sensitivity of IGRA was 92.3% (95% CI, 89.6%-94.4%). The proportions of IGRA-negative and -indeterminate results were 4.8% (95% CI, 3.1%-7.0%) and 3.0% (95% CI, 1.7%-4.9%). Age increased by year, body mass index <16.0, HIV co-infection and the increased number of HLA-DRB1*0701 allele that patients bear showed significant associations with IGRA negativity (OR = 1.04 [95% CI, 1.01-1.07], 5.42 [1.48-19.79], 6.38 [1.78-22.92] and 5.09 [2.31-11.22], respectively). HIV co-infection and the same HLA allele were also associated with indeterminate results (OR = 99.59 [95% CI, 15.58-625.61] and 4.25 [1.27-14.16]). Conclusions: Aging, emaciation, HIV co-infection and HLA genotype affected IGRA results. Assessment of these factors might contribute to a better understanding of the assay. © 2011 Hang et al. © 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Identification and characterization of an oocyte factor required for development of porcine nuclear transfer embryos
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan; Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; National Institute of Radiological Sciences Chiba, Chiba, Japan; Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Shizuoka Prefectural Research Institute of Animal Industry, Kikugawa, Shizuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyamoto, Kei, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Nagai, Kouhei, Department of Genetic Development, Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan; Kitamura, Naoya, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Nishikawa, Tomoaki, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Ikegami, Haruka, Department of Genetic Development, Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan; Binh, Nguyen Tran Thi, Organization of Advanced Science and Technology, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan, Faculty of Animal Science and Veterinary Medicine, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tsukamoto, Satoshi, Laboratory Animal and Genome Sciences Section, National Institute of Radiological Sciences Chiba, Chiba, Japan; Matsumoto, Mai, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Tsukiyama, Tomoyuki, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan; Minami, Naojirou, Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: Nuclear reprogramming of differentiated cells can be induced by oocyte factors. Despite numerous attempts, these factors and mechanisms responsible for successful reprogramming remain elusive. Here, we identify one such factor, necessary for the development of nuclear transfer embryos, using porcine oocyte extracts in which some reprogramming events are recapitulated. After incubating somatic nuclei in oocyte extracts from the metaphase II stage, the oocyte proteins that were specifically and abundantly incorporated into the nuclei were identified by mass spectrometry. Among 25 identified proteins, we especially focused on a multi-functional protein, DJ-1. DJ-1 is present at a high concentration in oocytes from the germinal vesicle stage until embryos at the four-cell stage. Inhibition of DJ-1 function compromises the development of nuclear transfer embryos but not that of fertilized embryos. Microarray analysis of nuclear transfer embryos in which DJ-1 function is inhibited shows perturbed expression of P53 pathway components. In addition, embryonic arrest of nuclear transfer embryos injected with anti-DJ-1 antibody is rescued by P53 inhibition. We conclude that DJ-1 is an oocyte factor that is required for development of nuclear transfer embryos. This study presents a means for identifying natural reprogramming factors in mammalian oocytes and a unique insight into the mechanisms underlying reprogramming by nuclear transfer. © 2011 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

(7102243595); Farnsworth, Elizabeth J. (7005620389); Fernando, Edwino Sanson (7004501972); Kathiresan, Kandasamy I. (7006251213); Koedam, Nico E. (7003384572)
Title: The loss of species: Mangrove extinction risk and geographic areas of global concern
Affiliations: Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Nature Conservancy, Arlington, United States; University of Plymouth, Plymouth, United Kingdom; The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Harvard Forest, Petersham, United States; University of Tasmania, Hobart, Australia; New England Wild Flower Society, Framingham, United States; University of the Philippines Los Banos, Los Banos, Philippines; Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Brussels, Belgium; Tohoku Gakuin University, Sendai, Japan; University of New Hampshire Durham, Durham, United States; Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Universiti Sains Malaysia, Gelugor, Malaysia; Southeast Asian Fisheries Development Center Philippines, Iloilo, Philippines; Central Luzon State University, Munoz, Philippines; Lembaga Ilmu Pengetahuan Indonesia, Central Jakarta, Indonesia; Shandong University, Weihai, Weihai, China; National Institute of Education, Singapore City, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Polidoro, Beth A., Department of Biological Sciences, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Carpenter, Kent E., Department of Biological Sciences, Old Dominion University, Norfolk, United States; Collins, Lorna, Center for Global Trends, Nature Conservancy, Arlington, United States, School of Biological Sciences, University of Plymouth, Plymouth, United Kingdom; Duke, Norman C., Centre for Marine Studies, The University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia; Ellison, Aaron M., Harvard Forest, Petersham, United States; Ellison, Joanna C., School of Geography and Environmental Studies, University of Tasmania, Hobart, Australia; Farnsworth, Elizabeth J., New England Wild Flower Society, Framingham, United States; Fernando, Edwino Sanson, Department of Forest Biological Sciences, University of the Philippines Los Banos, Los Banos, Philippines; Kathiresan, Kandasamy I., Centre of Advanced Study in Marine Biology, Annamalai University, Chidambaram, India; Koedam, Nico E., Faculty of Sciences and Bioengineering Sciences, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Mangrove species are uniquely adapted to tropical and subtropical coasts, and although relatively low in number of species, mangrove forests provide at least US $1.6 billion each year in ecosystem services and support coastal livelihoods worldwide. Globally, mangrove areas are declining rapidly as they are cleared for coastal development and aquaculture and logged for timber and fuel production. Little is known about the effects of mangrove area loss on individual mangrove species and local or regional populations. To address this gap, species-specific information on global distribution, population status, life history traits, and major threats were compiled for each of the 70 known species of mangroves. Each species' probability of extinction was assessed under the Categories and Criteria of the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Eleven of the 70 mangrove species (16%) are at elevated threat of extinction. Particular areas of geographical concern include the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of Central America, where as many as 40% of mangroves species present are threatened with extinction. Across the globe, mangrove species found primarily in the high intertidal and upstream estuarine zones, which often have specific freshwater requirements and patchy distributions, are the most threatened because they are often the first cleared for development of aquaculture and agriculture. The loss of mangrove species will have devastating economic and environmental consequences for coastal communities, especially in those areas with low mangrove diversity and high mangrove area or species loss. Several species at high risk of extinction may disappear well before the next decade if existing protective measures are not enforced. © 2010 Polidoro et al. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Climate as a contributing factor in the demise of Angkor, Cambodia
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, United States; The University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia; The University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan; Bidoup-Núi Bà National Park, Viet Nam; Chiang Mai Rajabhat University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Buckley, Brendan M., Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, United States; Anchukaitis, Kevin J., Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, United States; Penny, Dan A., School of Geosciences, The University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Fletcher, Roland J., Department of Archaeology, The University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia; Cook, Edward R., Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, United States; Sano, Masaki, Department of Agriculture, Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan; Nam, Le Canh, Bidoup-Núi Bà National Park, Viet Nam; Wichienkeeo, Aroonrut, Department of History, Chiang Mai Rajabhat University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Minh, Ton That, Bidoup-Núi Bà National Park, Viet Nam; Hong, Truong Mai, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The "hydraulic city" of Angkor, the capitol of the Khmer Empire in Cambodia, experienced decades-long drought interspersed with intense monsoons in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries that, in combination with other factors, contributed to its eventual demise. The climatic evidence comes from a seven-and-a-half century robust hydroclimate reconstruction from tropical southern Vietnamese tree rings. The Angkor droughts were of a duration and severity that would have impacted the sprawling city's water supply and agricultural productivity, while high-magnitude monsoon years damaged its water control infrastructure. Hydroclimate variability for this region is strongly and inversely correlated with tropical Pacific sea surface temperature, indicating that a warm Pacific and El Niño events induce drought at interannual and interdecadal time scales, and that low-frequency variations of tropical Pacific climate can exert significant influence over Southeast Asian climate and society. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Authors: T., Le, Tungdinh; Y., Shirai, Yoshinori; T., Okamoto, Takehito; T., Tatsukawa, Tetsuya; S., Nagao, Soichi; T., Shimizu, Takao; M., Ito, Masao
Author full names: Le, Tungdinh (36087442500); Shirai, Yoshinori (7202788850); Okamoto, Takehito (16033526400); Tatsukawa, Tetsuya (13613920600); Nagao, Soichi (7202295031); Shimizu, Takao (55625858800); Ito, Masao (55726705300)
Title: Lipid signaling in cytosolic phospholipase A2α- cyclooxygenase-2 cascade mediates cerebellar longterm depression and motor learning
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; Faculty of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Le, Tungdinh, Ito Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan, Department of Physiology, Hanoi Medical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Shirai, Yoshinori, Ito Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; Okamoto, Takehito, Nagao Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; Tatsukawa, Tetsuya, Nagao Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; Nagao, Soichi, Nagao Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan; Shimizu, Takao, Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Ito, Masao, Ito Laboratory, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, Wako, Japan
Abstract: In this study, we show the crucial roles of lipid signaling in longterm depression (LTD), that is, synaptic plasticity prevailing in cerebellar Purkinje cells. In mouse brain slices, we found that cPLA<inf>2</inf>α knockout blocked LTD induction, which was rescued by replenishing arachidonic acid (AA) or prostaglandin (PG) D<inf>2</inf> or E<inf>2</inf>. Moreover, cyclooxygenase (COX)-2 inhibitors block LTD, which is rescued by supplementing PGD <inf>2</inf>/E<inf>2</inf>. The blockade or rescue occurs when these reagents are applied within a time window of 5-15 min following the onset of LTD-inducing stimulation. Furthermore, PGD<inf>2</inf>/E<inf>2</inf> facilitates the chemical induction of LTD by a PKC activator but is unable to rescue the LTD blocked by a PKC inhibitor. We conclude that PGD<inf>2</inf>/E<inf>2</inf> mediates LTD jointly with PKC, and suggest possible pathways for their interaction. Finally, we demonstrate in awake mice that cPLA<inf>2</inf>α deficiency or COX-2 inhibition attenuates short-term adaptation of optokinetic eye movements, supporting the view that LTD underlies motor learning. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Author full names: Kiso, Maki (19934079800); Takahashi, Kazumi (55881697900); Sakai-Tagawa, Yuko T. (8683348700); Shinya, Kyoko (7004441613); Sakabe, Saori (21834989800); Lê, Maithi Quynh (14525254100); Ozawa, Makoto (35345736600); Furuta, Yousuke (7102112720); Kawaoka, Yoshihiro K. (26643027000)
Title: T-705 (favipiravir) activity against lethal H5N1 influenza A viruses
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; FUJIFILM Toyama Chemical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kiso, Maki, Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Takahashi, Kazumi, Central Research Laboratory, FUJIFILM Toyama Chemical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Sakai-Tagawa, Yuko T., Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Shinya, Kyoko, Department of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Sakabe, Saori, Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Lê, Maithi Quynh, National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ozawa, Makoto, Institute of Medical Science, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Pathological Sciences, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Furuta, Yousuke, Central Research Laboratory, FUJIFILM Toyama Chemical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan; Kawaoka, Yoshihiro K., Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, Kobe University, Kobe, Japan, Institute of Medical Science, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Pathological Sciences, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States, Exploratory Research for Advanced Technology Infection-Induced Host Responses Project, Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Japan
Abstract: The neuraminidase inhibitors oseltamivir and zanamivi are used to treat H5N1 influenza. However, oseltamivir-resistant H5N1 viruses have been isolated from oseltamivir-treated patients. Moreover, reassortment between H5N1 viruses and oseltamvir-resistant human H1N1 viruses currently circulating could create oseltamivirresistant H5N1 viruses, rendering the oseltamivir stockpile obsolete. Therefore, there is a need for unique and effective antivirals to combat H5N1 influenza viruses. The investigational drug T-705 (favipiravir; 6-fluoro-3-hydroxy-2-pyrazinecarboxamide) has antiviral activity against seasonal influenza viruses and a mouseadapted H5N1 influenza virus derived from a benign duck virus. However, its efficacy against highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses, which are substantially more virulent, remains unclear. Here, we demonstrate that T-705 effectively protects mice from lethal infection with oseltamivir-sensitive or -resistant highly pathogenic H5N1 viruses. Furthermore, our biochemical analysis suggests that T-705 ribofuranosyl triphosphate, an active form of T-705, acts like purines or purine nucleosides in human cells and does not inhibit human DNA synthesis. We conclude that T-705 shows promise as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza patients. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Author full names: Lien, Luu Thi (16307328500); Hang, Nguyen Thi Le (23392324300); Kobayashi, Nobuyuki (58996079700); Yanai, Hideki (7102313174); Toyota, Emiko (7005471835); Sakurada, Shinsaku (7102176410); Thuong, Pham Huu (35112416900); Cuong, Vu Cao (35112337300); Nanri, Akiko (23971189700); Mizoue, Tetsuya (7006894381)
Title: Prevalence and risk factors for tuberculosis infection among hospital workers in Hanoi, Viet Nam
Affiliations: Hanoi Tuberculosis and Lung Disease Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; NHO Tokyo Medical Center, Tokyo, Japan; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Hanoi Tuberculosis and Lung Disease Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; The Research Institute of Tuberculosis, Japan Anti-Tuberculosis Association, Kiyose, Japan; Hanoi Department of Health, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Lien, Luu Thi, Hanoi Tuberculosis and Lung Disease Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hang, Nguyen Thi Le, Bach Mai Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Nobuyuki, Department of Respiratory Medicine, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Yanai, Hideki, Institute of Tropical Medicine, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan; Toyota, Emiko, Department of Respiratory Diseases, NHO Tokyo Medical Center, Tokyo, Japan; Sakurada, Shinsaku, Department of Respiratory Diseases, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Thuong, Pham Huu, Hanoi Tuberculosis and Lung Disease Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cuong, Vu Cao, General Planning Department, Hanoi Tuberculosis and Lung Disease Hospital, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nanri, Akiko, Department of Epidemiology and International Health, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan; Mizoue, Tetsuya, Department of Epidemiology and International Health, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Background: Transmission of tuberculosis (TB) to health care workers (HCWs) is a global issue. Although effective infection control measures are expected to reduce nosocomial TB, HCWs' infection has not been assessed enough in TB high burden countries. We conducted a cross-sectional study to determine the prevalence of TB infection and its risk factors among HCWs in Hanoi, Viet Nam. Methodology/Principal Findings: A total of 300 HCWs including all staff members in a municipal TB referral hospital received an interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA), QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tub™, followed by one- and two-step tuberculin skin test (TST) and a questionnaire-based interview. Agreement between the tests was evaluated by kappa statistics. Risk factors for TB infection were analyzed using a logistic regression model. Among the participants aged from 20 to 58 years (median = 40), prevalence of TB infection estimated by IGRA, one- and two-step TST was 47.3%, 61.1% and 66.3% respectively. Although the levels of overall agreement between IGRA and TST were moderate, the degree of agreement was low in the group with BCG history (kappa = 0.29). Working in TB hospital was associated with twofold increase in odds of TB infection estimated by IGRA. Increased age, low educational level and the high body mass index also demonstrated high odds ratios of IGRA positivity. Conclusions/Significance: Prevalence of TB infection estimated by either IGRA or TST is high among HCWs in the hospital environment for TB care in Viet Nam and an infection control program should be reinforced. In communities with heterogeneous history of BCG vaccination, IGRA seems to estimate TB infection more accurately than any other criteria using TST. © 2009 Lien et al. © 2009 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Z., Li, Zhen; Y., Saito, Yoshiki; P.X., Dang, Phong X.; E., Matsumoto, Eiji; L., Quang, Lanvu
Author full names: Li, Zhen (55045130000); Saito, Yoshiki (57205687039); Dang, Phong X. (24832615700); Matsumoto, Eiji (7102921527); Quang, Lanvu (36917440700)
Title: Warfare rather than agriculture as a critical influence on fires in the late Holocene, inferred from northern Vietnam
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: East China Normal University, Shanghai, China; National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Li, Zhen, East China Normal University, Shanghai, China; Saito, Yoshiki, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Dang, Phong X., Institute of Geography, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Matsumoto, Eiji, Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Nagoya University, Nagoya, Japan; Quang, Lanvu,
Abstract: Fire has played an essential role in the development of human civilization. Most previous research suggests that frequent-fire regimes in the late Holocene were associated with intensification of human activities, especially agriculture development. Here, we analyze fire regimes recorded in the Song Hong delta area of Vietnam over the past 5,000 years. In the prehistoric period, 2 long-term, low-charcoal abundance periods have been linked to periods of low humidity and cool climate, and 5 short-term fire regimes of 100-150 years in duration occurred at regular intervals of ≈700 years. However, over the last 1,500 years, the number, frequency, and intensity of fire regimes clearly increased. Six intensified-fire regime periods in northern Vietnam during this time coincided with changes of Vietnamese dynasties and associated warfare and unrest. In contrast, agricultural development supported by rulers of stable societies at this time does not show a positive correlation with intensified-fire regime periods. Thus, warfare rather than agriculture appears to have been a critical factor contributing to fire regimes in northern Vietnam during the late Holocene. © 2010 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.; MEDLINE® is the source for the MeSH terms of this document.

Title: Phylogeny and ancient DNA of Sus provides insights into neolithic expansion in Island Southeast Asia and Oceania

Affiliations: Biomedicinskt centrum, Uppsala, Sweden; Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, Honolulu, United States; The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Rural Development Administration, Jeonju, South Korea; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Istituto Nazionale per la Fauna Selvatica, Ozzano Dell'emilia, Italy; Indonesian Centre for Archaeology, Jakarta, Indonesia; National Institutes for the Humanities National Museum of Ethnology, Suita, Japan; University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, United States; Academia Sinica, Institute of History and Philology, Taipei, Taiwan; University of New England Australia, Armidale, Australia; University of York, York, United Kingdom; University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, 't Horntje, Netherlands; Naval Facilities Engineering Systems Command Pacific, Honolulu, United States; UiT Norges Arktiske Universitet, Tromso, Norway; Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing, China; Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France; University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Larson, Greger, Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology, Biomedicinskt centrum, Uppsala, Sweden, Department of Zoology, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom; Cucchi, Thomas, Department of Archaeology, Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom, Département Ecologie et Gestion de la Biodiversité, Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France; Fujita, Masakatsu, Department of Archaeology, Durham University, Durham, United Kingdom; Matisoo-Smith, Elizabeth A., Department of Anthropology, The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Robins, Judith H., Department of Anthropology, The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Anderson, Atholl J., Department of Archaeology and Natural History, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Rolett, Barry V., Department of Anthropology, University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, Honolulu, United States; Spriggs, Matthew J.T., School of Archaeology and Anthropology, The Australian National University, Canberra, Australia; Dolman, Gaynor, Australian Centre for Ancient DNA, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, Australia; Kim, Tae-hun, Animal Genomics and Bioinformatics Division, Rural Development Administration, Jeonju, South Korea
Abstract: Human settlement of Oceania marked the culmination of a global colonization process that began when humans first left Africa at least 90,000 years ago. The precise origins and dispersal routes of the Austronesian peoples and the associated Lapita culture remain contentious, and numerous disparate models of dispersal (based primarily on linguistic, genetic, and archeological data) have been proposed. Here, through the use of mtDNA from 781 modern and ancient Sus specimens, we provide evidence for an early human-mediated translocation of the Sulawesi warty pig (Sus celebensis) to Flores and Timor and two later separate human-mediated dispersals of domestic pig (Sus scrofa) through Island Southeast Asia into Oceania. Of the later dispersal routes, one is unequivocally associated with the Neolithic (Lapita) and later Polynesian migrations and links modern and archeological Javan, Sumatran, Wallacean, and Oceanic pigs with mainland Southeast Asian S. scrofa. Archeological and genetic evidence shows these pigs were certainly introduced to islands east of the Wallace Line, including New Guinea, and that so-called "wild" pigs within this region are most likely feral descendants of domestic pigs introduced by early agriculturalists. The other later pig dispersal links mainland East Asian pigs to western Micronesia, Taiwan, and the Philippines. These results provide important data with which to test current models for human dispersal in the region. © 2007 by The National Academy of Sciences of the USA. © 2008 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Study of astrophysically important resonant states in 26Si by the 28Si(4He,6He)26Si reaction
Affiliations: Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Institute of Physics and Electronics, Viet Nam; KEK (The High Energy Accelerator Organization, Japan; McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada; Yamagata University, Yamagata, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kwon, Youngkwan, Department of Physics, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Lee, Chun-sik, Department of Physics, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Moon, Junyoung, Department of Physics, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Lee, Ju-hahn, Department of Physics, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, Jin Young, Department of Physics, Chung-Ang University, Seoul, South Korea; Kubono, Shigeru, Center for Nuclear Study, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Iwasa, Naohito, Department of Physics, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Inafuku, K., Department of Physics, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Yamaguchi, Hidetoshi, Center for Nuclear Study, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; He, Jiangjun, Center for Nuclear Study, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The emission of 1.809 MeV gamma-ray from the first excited state of 26Mg followed by betadecay of 26Al in its ground state (denoted as 26Alg.s.) has been identified by gamma-ray telescopes such the Compton Gamma-Ray Observatory (CGRO) [1]. To resolve controversy over the possible sources of the observational 1.809 MeV gamma-rays, one needs accurate knowledge of the production rate of 26Al. The 25Al(p,γ )26Si reaction which is the competition reaction for production of 26Alg.s. is one of the important subjects to be investigated. In this work, the astrophysically important 26Si states above the proton threshold were studied via the 28Si( 4He,6He)26Si reaction. We have preformed an angular distribution measurement using the high resolution QDD spectrograph (PA) at Center for Nuclear Study (CNS), University of Tokyo. The experimental results and data analysis will be presented. © Copyright owned by the author(s). © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Abstract: We have studied the proton resonance scattering of 7Be by using a pure 7Be beam produced at CRIB (CNS Radioactive Ion Beam separator; CNS stands for Center of Nuclear Study, University of Tokyo). The excitation function of 8B was measured up to the excitation energy of 6.8 MeV, using the thick-target method. The excited states of 8B higher than 3.5 MeV were not known by the past experiments. This proton elastic scattering is also of importance in relation with the 7Be(p,γ) 8B reaction, which is a key reaction in the standard solar model. © Copyright owned by the author(s). © 2013 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Haemagglutinin mutations responsible for the binding of H5N1 influenza A viruses to human-type receptors

Abstract: H5N1 influenza A viruses have spread to numerous countries in Asia, Europe and Africa, infecting not only large numbers of poultry, but also an increasing number of humans, often with lethal effects. Human and avian influenza A viruses differ in their recognition of host cell receptors: the former preferentially recognize receptors with saccharides terminating in sialic acid-α2,6- galactose (SAα2,6Gal), whereas the latter prefer those ending in SAα2,3Gal (refs 3-6). A conversion from SAα2,3Gal to SAα2,6Gal recognition is thought to be one of the changes that must occur before avian influenza viruses can replicate efficiently in humans and acquire the potential to cause a pandemic. By identifying mutations in the receptor-binding haemagglutinin (HA) molecule that would enable avian H5N1 viruses to recognize human-type host cell receptors, it may be possible to predict (and thus to increase preparedness for) the emergence of pandemic viruses. Here we show that some H5N1 viruses isolated from humans can bind to both human and avian receptors, in contrast to those isolated from chickens and ducks, which recognize the avian receptors exclusively. Mutations at positions 182 and 192 independently convert the HAs of H5N1 viruses known to recognize the avian receptor to ones that recognize the human receptor. Analysis of the crystal structure of the HA from an H5N1 virus used in our genetic experiments shows that the locations of these amino acids in the HA molecule are compatible with an effect on receptor binding. The amino acid changes that we identify might serve as molecular markers for assessing the pandemic potential of H5N1 field isolates. ©2006 Nature Publishing Group. © 2015 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Red Cross Saitama Blood Ctr., Saitama-Ken, Japan; Mishiro, Shunji, Institute of Immunology Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Miyakawa, Yuzo, Mita Institute, Tokyo, Japan; Mayumi, Makoto, Jichi Medical University, Kawachi District, Japan, Immunology Division, Jichi Medical University, Kawachi District, Japan
Abstract: Thirty-four (41%) of 83 hepatitis C virus (HCV) isolates from commercial blood donors in Vietnam were not classifiable into genotype I/1a, II/1b, III/2a, IV/2b, or V/3a; for 15 of them, the sequence was determined for 1.6 kb in the 5'-terminal region and 1.1 kb in the 3'-terminal region. Comparison of the 15 Vietnamese isolates among themselves and with reported full or partial HCV genomic sequences indicated that they were classifiable into four major groups (groups 6-9) divided into six genotypes (6a, 7a, 7b, 8a, 8b, and 9a). Vietnamese HCV isolates of genotypes 7a, 7b, 8a, 8b, and 9a were significantly different from those classified into groups 4, 5, and 6 based on divergence within partial sequences; those of genotype 6a were homologous to a Hong Kong isolate (HK2) of genotype 6a. Phylogenetic trees based on the envelope 1 (E1) gene (576 bp) of 55 isolates and a part of the nonstructural 5 (NS5) region (1093 bp) of 43 isolates revealed at least nine major groups, three of which (groups 7, 8, and 9) were identified only in Vietnamese blood donors. With a prospect that many more HCV isolates with significant sequence divergence will be reported from all over the world, the domain of the HCV genome to be compared and criteria for grouping/typing and genotyping/subtyping will have to be determined, so that they may be correlated with virological, epidemiological, and clinical characteristics. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
